sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para:
The Diamond application enables you to view image files.
Diamond provides the following features:

listitem.para: Support for the following image file formats:
BMP - Windows Bitmap
GIF - Graphics Interchange Format
ICO - Windows Icon
JPEG - Joint Photographic Experts Group
PNG - Portable Network Graphics
PNM - Portable Anymap from the PPM Toolkit
RAS - Sun Raster
TIFF - Tagged Image File Format
XPM - X Pixmap
A variety of zoom levels and full screen viewing, with low usage of memory regardless of the zoom level.
Bonobo embedding technology that enables you to embed image views in other GNOME applications.

sect2.title: To Start MY-GNOME-APPLICATION
sect2.para:
You can start
MY-GNOME-APPLICATION
in the following ways:

listitem.para:
Choose
Submenu Name My-GNOME-APPLICATION
.

where
filename.jpg is the name of the file you want to open.
MY-GNOME-APPLICATION opens each file that you specify in a new window.

sect2.title: When You Start MY-GNOME-APPLICATION
sect2.para:
When you start
MY-GNOME-APPLICATION
, the following window is displayed.

textobject.phrase: Shows MY-GNOME-APPLICATION main window. Contains titlebar, menubar, toolbar, display area, and scrollbars. Menubar contains File, View, Settings, and Help menus.

sect2.para: The MY-GNOME-APPLICATION window contains the following elements:

listitem.para:
The menus on the menubar contain all of the commands you need to work with files in
MY-GNOME-APPLICATION
.
The toolbar contains a subset of the commands that you can access from the menubar.

The statusbar displays information about current
MY-GNOME-APPLICATION
activity and contextual information about the menu items.

sect1.title: Usage
sect1.para: You can use the MY-GNOME-APPLICATION application to perform the following tasks:

sect2.title: To Open an Image
sect2.para:
To open an image, choose
File Open Image
. The
Open Image dialog is displayed. Select the file that you want to open, then click
OK . To open another image in a new window, choose
File Create New Window
. Choose
File Open Image
to select the file that you want to open. You can also drag an image from another application such as a file manager to the MY-GNOME-APPLICATION
window. If the MY-GNOME-APPLICATION window is empty, the application displays the image in the window. If the window is not empty, the application starts a new window to display the file. The application displays the name of the image file and the size of the image in pixels in the titlebar of the window.
If you try to open an image file format that MY-GNOME-APPLICATION does not recognize, the application displays an error message.

sect2.title: To Manipulate the View of an Image
sect2.para: You can use the following methods to resize the view of an image in the MY-GNOME-APPLICATION window:

listitem.para:
To enlarge the view of an image, choose
View Zoom In
.

To shrink the view of an image, choose
View Zoom Out
.

To view the image at its actual size, choose
View Zoom 1:1
.

To enlarge or shrink the view of an image so that the image fits the MY-GNOME-APPLICATION window, choose
View Fit to Window
.

To enlarge or shrink the image to a specific zoom factor, choose
View Zoom factor
, then choose the appropriate zoom factor from the drop-down list.

To display the image in full screen mode, choose
View Full Screen
. Full screen mode displays the image in a window that fills the full screen. The window does not contain a window frame, titlebar, menubar, or toolbar. To exit from this mode, press the
Esc key or
Ctrl W
.

sect2.title: To Scroll an Image
sect2.para: To scroll around an image that is larger than the image window or full screen window, you can use the following methods:

listitem.para: Use the arrow keys on the keyboard.
Drag the image in the opposite direction to the direction in which you want to scroll. For example, if you want to scroll down the image, drag the image upwards in the window.
Use the scrollbars on the window.

sect2.title: To Close an Image
sect2.para:
To close an image, choose
File Close This Window
. If the window is the last
MY-GNOME-APPLICATION window open, the application exits.

To quit MY-GNOME-APPLICATION and close all of the windows that you opened in the current session, choose
File Exit
.

sect1.title: Settings
sect1.para:
To configure MY-GNOME-APPLICATION , choose
Settings Preferences
. The
Preferences dialog contains the following tabbed sections:

listitem.para:
Use this drop-down list box to specify the interpolation method that
MY-GNOME-APPLICATION uses when the application resizes images. Select one of the following options:

This method of interpolation takes a location in the original image and replicates the pixel that is nearest to this location. When you zoom in on an image, the pixels are replicated. When you zoom out of an image, the image loses some of its detail.

This is a simple and fast method of interpolation. When you zoom in on an image, MY-GNOME-APPLICATION uses up to four adjacent pixels to compute the colors of the new pixels. When you zoom out of an image, MY-GNOME-APPLICATION averages regions of color in the existing image to compute the colors of the pixels.
This is a high-quality, slow method of interpolation. The application performs interpolation on the image in the manner described in Digital Image Warping by George Wolberg.

Default:
Nearest neighbor .

Use this drop-down list box to specify how
MY-GNOME-APPLICATION displays transparent or partially opaque backgrounds in images. Select one of the following options:
This option displays black and dark gray checks.
This option displays dark gray and light gray checks.
This option displays light gray and white checks.
This option displays solid black.
This option displays solid gray.
This option displays solid white.

Default:
Dark checks .

Use this drop-down list box to specify the size of the checks to use to display transparent or partially opaque backgrounds in images. This option is only relevant if you choose
Dark checks ,
Midtone checks , or
Light checks from the
Transparency type drop-down list box. Select one of the following options:

Default:
Small .

Use this drop-down list box to specify the dithering method to use to display images. Dithering is a technique that is used to simulate colors in the original image file but that your system can not display. Select one of the following options:
This option does not use dithering.
This option performs dithering on pseudocolor displays, which use a limited palette of colors.
This option performs dithering on pseudocolor and high color displays.

Default:
None .

Select this option to render an image in two passes when you scroll the image quickly. The first pass renders a low quality version of the image. The second pass renders a full quality version of the image over the low quality version. Two-pass scrolling enables you to view at least a low quality version of the image at all times regardless of how quickly you scroll the image.
Default: unselected.

sect2.title: Viewers
sect2.para: You can set the following viewer preferences:

sect3.title: Image Windows
sect3.para:
The
Image Windows group contains the preferences that you can set to view images in image windows.

listitem.para: Use this drop-down list box to specify when to use scrollbars to scroll through an image. Select one of the following options:
This option never displays scrollbars. You can use the arrow keys on the keyboard or the mouse to scroll through the image.

para.guilabel: Only if image does not fit

listitem.para: This option displays scrollbars when the image is larger than the image window.

Default:
Never .

term.guilabel: Pick window size and zoom factor automatically

listitem.para:
Select this option to resize the image window to fit the image or to resize the image to fit the image window. If the image is small,
MY-GNOME-APPLICATION resizes the image window to fit the image. If the image is large, MY-GNOME-APPLICATION resizes the image to fit the image window.
Default: unselected.

term.guilabel: Open images in a new window

listitem.para:
Select this option to open a new
MY-GNOME-APPLICATION window each time you open an image. If you do not select this option, MY-GNOME-APPLICATION replaces the existing image with the new image when you open an image.
Default: unselected.

sect3.title: Full Screen
sect3.para:
The
Full Screen group contains the preferences that you can set to view images in full screen mode.

listitem.para: Use this drop-down list box to specify when to use scrollbars to scroll through an image. Select one of the following options:
This option never displays scrollbars. You can use the arrow keys on the keyboard or the mouse to scroll through the image.

para.guilabel: Only if image does not fit

listitem.para: This option displays scrollbars when the image is larger than the full screen.

Default:
Never .
Select this option to use the 1:1 zoom factor when you open an image. The 1:1 zoom factor displays the image at its actual size.
Default: selected.

term.guilabel: Use same zoom factor as image window

listitem.para: Select this option to use the same zoom factor that the application uses to display the image in an image window.
Default: unselected.
Select this option to resize images to fill the full screen when you open the images in full screen mode.
Default: unselected.

Select this option to automatically resize images that are the same size as standard screens so that the images fill the full screen when you open them in full screen mode. If you select this option, MY-GNOME-APPLICATION ignores the settings for the previous three options when you open an image that is the same size as a standard screen. Examples of standard screen sizes are 640 x 480 pixels, 1024 x 768 pixels, and so on.
Default: unselected.

term.guilabel: Put a bevel around the edge of the screen

listitem.para: Select this option to display a 3D beveled border around the full screen view of an image.
Default: unselected.
